title: US Banks‚Äô Push To Ban Stablecoin Rewards Could Hand Global Advantage To China, Execs Warn
body: After China‚Äôs latest move with its Digital Yuan, multiple crypto industry executives have cautioned that the US banks‚Äô push to prohibit all interest payments on stablecoins could give a major advantage to their global rivals. US Risks Giving China A Major Global Advantage On Tuesday, Coinbase‚Äôs Chief Policy Officer (CPO), Faryar Shirzad, warned the US Congress that banning interest payments on the digital assets could risk diminishing the legislative efforts and victories obtained this year with the Guiding and Establishing National Innovation for U.S. Stablecoins (GENIUS) Act. In an X post, Shirzad affirmed that ‚Äútokenization is the future and the GENIUS Act was a visionary move by POTUS and Congress to ensure US dollar stablecoins issued under US rules would be the primary settlement instrument of the future.‚Äù However, Shirzad noted that the ‚Äúsobering and timely‚Äù announcement by the People‚Äôs Bank of China of its plan to pay interest on the Digital Yuan could pose a bigger problem to the US than investors think. As reported by Bitcoinist, China is about to start paying interest on its Digital Yuan (e-CNY). Deputy Governor at the People‚Äôs Bank of China, Lu Lei, recently shared a new framework that will redefine the rules of virtual currency, giving it the same legal status as deposits held at banks. Under the new framework , commercial banks that manage Digital Yuan wallets will be able to pay interest to clients based on the amount of e-CNY they hold, starting from January 1, 2026. Based on this, Shirzad cautioned that ‚ÄúIf this issue is mishandled in Senate negotiations on the market structure bill, it could hand our global rivals a big assist in giving non-US stablecoins and CBDCs a critical competitive advantage at the worst possible time.‚Äù Stablecoin Rewards: A ‚ÄòMatter Of National Security‚Äô Coinbase‚Äôs CPO added that although ‚Äúlobbyists for entrenched incumbents will always fight change,‚Äù it‚Äôs crucial for Congress to ‚Äúprotect the primacy of the US dollar and the US financial system, ‚Äúnot just incumbent interests.‚Äù Similarly, other crypto executives agreed with Shirzad‚Äôs statement, including Coinbase‚Äôs Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Brian Armstrong and Variant‚Äôs Chief Legal Officer (CLO) Jake Chervinsky. Armstrong emphasized that US ‚Äústablecoins must remain competitive on a global stage. Meanwhile, Chervinsky asserted that banks‚Äô push to ban stablecoin rewards ‚Äúisn‚Äôt just a matter of incumbents seeking a regulatory moat. It‚Äôs a matter of national security.‚Äù To the lawyer, revisiting the issue of interest payments on USD-pegged tokens would weaken the victory that the GENIUS Act gave to US dollar dominance worldwide and ‚Äúhand that win to China.‚Äù Notably, the banking sector has criticized the US‚Äôs landmark stablecoin legislation over the past few months, arguing that it has loopholes that could pose risks to the financial system. The crypto framework, which was signed into law by President Trump in July, prohibits interest payments on the holding or use of payment-purpose stablecoins. Nonetheless, the prohibition only addresses issuers, meaning that it could be ‚Äúeasily circumvented‚Äù by exchanges or affiliates providing rewards. Earlier this year, multiple banking associations across the US sent a joint letter to the Senate Banking Committee urging Congress to amend the law. The banking groups claimed that interest payments would distort market dynamics and could affect credit creation. Therefore, they suggested extending the prohibition to include digital asset exchanges, brokers, dealers, and related entities. Shirzad, alongside multiple crypto industry players, has rejected these concerns over the past several months, stating that the banking sector‚Äôs proposals could threaten to create an uncompetitive environment for USD-denominated tokens. In October, Coinbase‚Äôs CPO slammed the financial institution‚Äôs narrative that stablecoins would destroy bank lending, concluding that it ‚Äúignores reality‚Äù and misreads the crucial moment.
